values.title: CEO and Founder
values.summary:
Relevant Learning (RL) is an educational non-profit that brings work relevancy and excitement into the classroom.  We partner with entrepreneurial companies that want to develop a deeper connection to students and the classroom by hosting highly skilled teachers to complete summer projects.  We  then support the teacher’s creation and delivery of innovative lesson plans based directly on their summer learning.  Students see their teachers as learners and see how what they are learning in the classroom connects to the world of work.

Relevant Learning was founded in September of 2014 by Brian H. Kaplan who hold and MBA from Berkeley and a MA. Ed. from Stanford.  Brian spent more than 15 years in the high tech sector before transitioning to non-profit work in 2008.  Brian has worked with innovative non-profits such as Silicon Valley Education Foundation, New Teacher Center, and College Track.   Brian has a son who will graduate this May from a top performing high school and has often asked, “How does what I am learning connect to relevant skills and practical things in the real world.”

I am primarily interested in understanding the basic biology of X chromosome during the transition from somatic cell to induced pluripotent stem cell. Using an mRNA reprogramming technique paired with single cell isolation and microfluidic gene expression assays, I have characterized the X chromosome status following reprogramming in human cells. values.summary: I am searching for new biomarkers of embryo viability to increase success rates of in vitro fertilization. values.title: PhD Candidate
values.summary:
Advisor: Dr. Manuel Amieva

I am investigating host and bacterial factors that are important for the human-specific pathogen Helicobacter pylori in colonizing the stomach. Using a novel chemotaxis assay that we developed, I have identified host metabolites in the stomach that direct H. pylori to the gastric epithelium where it ultimately cause disease (peptic ulcers, and gastric cancer). I have also identified the bacterial proteins that H. pylori uses to detect these metabolites. The goal of my studies is to better understand strategies that H. pylori uses to initiate colonization and persist in the stomach.

This research was presented at the 5th ASM Conference on Beneficial Microbes, the 2014 Gordon Research Conference on Microbial Stress Response, and the 17th Annual Bay Area Microbial Pathogenesis Symposium. A manuscript is in preparation.
